item.title: 704.server or something help
item.dc:creator: @ExtremeX-Scape Ryley
item.description:
@ExtremeX-Scape wrote:

^No, you cannot simply split a String like that to hold two usernames.

final String name = player.getUsername(); if ((name.equals("name1")) || name.equals("name2"))) { // the rest of your if block. }

Read full topic

item.title: 704.server or something help
item.dc:creator: @Ruby_Forums_Coder Ruby
item.description:
@Ruby_Forums_Coder wrote:

&& (player.getUsername().equalsIgnoreCase("owner_pk"))) {

Would be

&& (player.getUsername().equalsIgnoreCase("owner_pk || OTHERUSERNAMEHERE"))) {

Read full topic

item.title: 704.server or something help
item.dc:creator: @ExtremeX-Scape Ryley
item.description:
@ExtremeX-Scape wrote:

&& equals “and”
|| equals “or”

If you would like to add another name you would need to use the operator ‘||’ because if you used ‘&&’ your name would have to be the first and second name. Which you cannot do.

Read full topic

item.title: 704.server or something help
item.dc:creator: @Skiire Skiire
item.description:
@Skiire wrote:

Continue building on. Just use the logical operators && to continue the sequence as shown.

EX:

&& (player.getUsername().equalsIgnoreCase("owner_pk"))) {

So, as you can see from the above, there’s two opening parenthesis. While there are three closing. This means there’s an argument before-hand as well. So, figure out where between the last group of ))) to place your logical operators (||) to continue listing player names.

Read full topic
